channel.title: Categories on Design. Think. Make. Break. Repeat.
channel.description: Recent content in Categories on Design. Think. Make. Break. Repeat.

item.title: 5 Whys
item.description: Uncovering root causes behind a problem statement The 5 whys method helps to find a potential root cause to any surface level problem.

item.title: Buy the Book
item.description: Buy the Book

item.title: Buy the Book
item.description: Buy the Book

item.title: A/B Testing
item.description: A is better than B … or is it? A/B testing is an evaluation method that consists of parallel testing two different versions of the same product, to decide which one is more suitable for a specific user need or business goal.

item.title: A/B Testing
item.description: A is better than B … or is it? A/B testing is an evaluation method that consists of parallel testing two different versions of the same product, to decide which one is more suitable for a specific user need or business goal.

item.title: Affinity Diagramming
item.description: Translating research data into user needs Affinity diagramming is a simple and cost effective systematic method for processing research data which is (typically) qualitative in nature.

item.title: Affinity Diagramming
item.description: Translating research data into user needs Affinity diagramming is a simple and cost effective systematic method for processing research data which is (typically) qualitative in nature.

item.title: Autobiographical Diaries
item.description: A starting point to think about the lives of others Autobiographical diaries, when used in design, document the use of everyday products or services through textual and visual means.

item.title: Autobiographical Diaries
item.description: A starting point to think about the lives of others Autobiographical diaries, when used in design, document the use of everyday products or services through textual and visual means.

item.title: Bodystorming
item.description: Thinking with your body Bodystorming is a form of brainstorming, with an emphasis on generating ideas and unexpected insights through physical exploration, experience and interaction.

item.title: Bodystorming
item.description: Thinking with your body Bodystorming is a form of brainstorming, with an emphasis on generating ideas and unexpected insights through physical exploration, experience and interaction.

item.title: Brainwriting 6-3-5
item.description: Building on each other’s ideas Brainwriting 6-3-5 is a form of brainstorming that was developed as a way of getting around the group dynamic issues that can plague conventional brainstorms.

item.title: Brainwriting 6-3-5
item.description: Building on each other’s ideas Brainwriting 6-3-5 is a form of brainstorming that was developed as a way of getting around the group dynamic issues that can plague conventional brainstorms.

item.title: Business Model Canvas
item.description: Visually designing the value a company offers The business model canvas provides a template for capturing the value a company offers to their customers.

item.title: Business Model Canvas
item.description: Visually designing the value a company offers The business model canvas provides a template for capturing the value a company offers to their customers.

item.title: Business Model Experimentation
item.description: Iteratively exploring ideas for business model designs Business model experimentation provides a structured exploration approach to test new ideas by exploring different aspects.

item.title: Business Model Experimentation
item.description: Iteratively exploring ideas for business model designs Business model experimentation provides a structured exploration approach to test new ideas by exploring different aspects.

item.title: Card Sorting
item.description: Seeing information from your user’s perspective Card sorting is a method that allows users and stakeholders to participate in the design of an information architecture.

item.title: Card Sorting
item.description: Seeing information from your user’s perspective Card sorting is a method that allows users and stakeholders to participate in the design of an information architecture.

item.title: Cartographic Mapping
item.description: Generating rich depictions of settings and practices in a problem domain Cartographic mapping is a mapping method with a particular focus on the mediating role of the mapmaking activity in mutual knowledge construction.

item.title: Cartographic Mapping
item.description: Generating rich depictions of settings and practices in a problem domain Cartographic mapping is a mapping method with a particular focus on the mediating role of the mapmaking activity in mutual knowledge construction.

item.title: Channel Mapping
item.description: Reaching your customers from all angles Channel mapping is a method that goes beyond listing the ways customers are contacted by a company to explore what a company’s brand value means to a particular customer.

item.title: Channel Mapping
item.description: Reaching your customers from all angles Channel mapping is a method that goes beyond listing the ways customers are contacted by a company to explore what a company’s brand value means to a particular customer.

item.title: Co-Design Workshops
item.description: Designing with your participants Co-design workshops bring users, customers, stakeholders and designers together to rapidly critique and iterate on design concepts, ensuring that the needs of the people we are designing for remain at the centre of the design process.

item.title: Co-Design Workshops
item.description: Designing with your participants Co-design workshops bring users, customers, stakeholders and designers together to rapidly critique and iterate on design concepts, ensuring that the needs of the people we are designing for remain at the centre of the design process.

item.title: Competitor Analysis
item.description: Knowing how you compare to those around you The competitor analysis method is a flexible approach for understanding where a product or service fits compared to offers available in the market.

item.title: Competitor Analysis
item.description: Knowing how you compare to those around you The competitor analysis method is a flexible approach for understanding where a product or service fits compared to offers available in the market.

item.title: Contextual Observation
item.description: Observing how people act in the wild Contextual observation can be used to study people’s behaviour in different environments, such as workplaces, homes, and public spaces.

item.title: Contextual Observation
item.description: Observing how people act in the wild Contextual observation can be used to study people’s behaviour in different environments, such as workplaces, homes, and public spaces.

item.title: Cultural Probes
item.description: Getting to know your users through playful and provocative tasks The cultural probes method supports divergent thinking by relying on playful and provocative tasks mediated by well-crafted items.

item.title: Cultural Probes
item.description: Getting to know your users through playful and provocative tasks The cultural probes method supports divergent thinking by relying on playful and provocative tasks mediated by well-crafted items.

item.title: Decision Matrices
item.description: Because making design decisions isn’t easy Decision matrices are used to systematically evaluate a range of options based on an initial set of criteria.

item.title: Decision Matrices
item.description: Because making design decisions isn’t easy Decision matrices are used to systematically evaluate a range of options based on an initial set of criteria.

item.title: Design Critique
item.description: Valuing the perspective of others Design critiques focus on evaluating existing ideas within a small team, to quickly yield valuable and constructive feedback.

item.title: Design Critique
item.description: Valuing the perspective of others Design critiques focus on evaluating existing ideas within a small team, to quickly yield valuable and constructive feedback.

item.title: Design by Metaphor
item.description: The power of seeing something as something else Metaphors can be applied in design to explore the problem domain from unusual and competing perspectives, and to reveal the hidden dimensions of a problem to be solved.

item.title: Design by Metaphor
item.description: The power of seeing something as something else Metaphors can be applied in design to explore the problem domain from unusual and competing perspectives, and to reveal the hidden dimensions of a problem to be solved.

item.title: Direct Experience Storyboards
item.description: Acting out user experiences when involving users is not possible Direct experience storyboards is a research method that combines the advantages of systematic observation, direct experience, documentation and storytelling, particularly in contextually sensitive situations.

item.title: Direct Experience Storyboards
item.description: Acting out user experiences when involving users is not possible Direct experience storyboards is a research method that combines the advantages of systematic observation, direct experience, documentation and storytelling, particularly in contextually sensitive situations.

item.title: Empathic Modelling
item.description: Putting yourself in someone else’s shoes Empathic modelling is a method that simulates some of the everyday challenges that people with reduced physical or perceptual abilities are experiencing, from a first-person perspective

item.title: Empathic Modelling
item.description: Putting yourself in someone else’s shoes Empathic modelling is a method that simulates some of the everyday challenges that people with reduced physical or perceptual abilities are experiencing, from a first-person perspective

item.title: Experience Prototyping
item.description: Turning ideas into something that can be experienced The experience prototyping method enables a focus on the user experience and context of use, rather than fixating on the product form and features.

item.title: Experience Prototyping
item.description: Turning ideas into something that can be experienced The experience prototyping method enables a focus on the user experience and context of use, rather than fixating on the product form and features.

item.title: Experience Sampling
item.description: Sampling people’s states, emotions and thoughts in real-time The experience sampling method (ESM) allows collecting real-time self-reporting data about subjective experiences such as mental state, emotions or thoughts.

item.title: Experience Sampling
item.description: Sampling people’s states, emotions and thoughts in real-time The experience sampling method (ESM) allows collecting real-time self-reporting data about subjective experiences such as mental state, emotions or thoughts.

item.title: Extreme Characters
item.description: Using the unique needs of extraordinary people as design inspiration The method of extreme characters allows going beyond considering the needs of typical and conventional users by prompting us to think about design solutions for extreme characters.

item.title: Extreme Characters
item.description: Using the unique needs of extraordinary people as design inspiration The method of extreme characters allows going beyond considering the needs of typical and conventional users by prompting us to think about design solutions for extreme characters.

item.title: Focus Groups
item.description: Gaining insights by observing and listening to group discussions Focus group involves a group of people having a discussion on a specific topic, eliciting understandings through asking questions and prompting conversations.

item.title: Focus Groups
item.description: Gaining insights by observing and listening to group discussions Focus group involves a group of people having a discussion on a specific topic, eliciting understandings through asking questions and prompting conversations.

item.title: Forced Associations
item.description: Unlikely matches lead to new ideas Forced association for idea generation combines disparate concepts, resulting in new ideas based around them.

item.title: Forced Associations
item.description: Unlikely matches lead to new ideas Forced association for idea generation combines disparate concepts, resulting in new ideas based around them.

item.title: Future Workshops
item.description: Collectively envisioning future solutions The future workshops method allows us to identify the problems related to a current situation, imagine alternative solutions, and outline an action plan for implementing these solutions.

item.title: Future Workshops
item.description: Collectively envisioning future solutions The future workshops method allows us to identify the problems related to a current situation, imagine alternative solutions, and outline an action plan for implementing these solutions.

item.title: Group Passing
item.description: Collaboratively coming up with new ideas The group passing technique ‘ also referred to as brainsketching technique ’ is a form of brainstorming that engages a team of people in collaboratively producing new ideas, solutions or design concepts.

item.title: Group Passing
item.description: Collaboratively coming up with new ideas The group passing technique ‘ also referred to as brainsketching technique ’ is a form of brainstorming that engages a team of people in collaboratively producing new ideas, solutions or design concepts.

item.title: Hero Stories
item.description: Envisioning ideas through speculative storytelling The hero stories method involves the creation and evaluation of speculative stories around key experiences that people might have with an envisioned product or service.

item.title: Hero Stories
item.description: Envisioning ideas through speculative storytelling The hero stories method involves the creation and evaluation of speculative stories around key experiences that people might have with an envisioned product or service.

item.title: Heuristic Evaluation
item.description: Testing your solution with domain experts Heuristic evaluation is a useful method for collecting feedback on early designs, within a short time span and at low cost, by involving domain experts.

item.title: Heuristic Evaluation
item.description: Testing your solution with domain experts Heuristic evaluation is a useful method for collecting feedback on early designs, within a short time span and at low cost, by involving domain experts.

item.title: Interaction Relabelling
item.description: Shifting focus from functionality to interaction possibilities Interaction relabelling encourages the exploration of design ideas by substituting the to-be-designed product or service with another existing object.

item.title: Interaction Relabelling
item.description: Shifting focus from functionality to interaction possibilities Interaction relabelling encourages the exploration of design ideas by substituting the to-be-designed product or service with another existing object.

item.title: Interviews
item.description: Only by asking good questions, will you get good answers Interviews are one of the most flexible research tools available to designers, and are used in many phases of the design process to gather information from experts, users and other stakeholders.

item.title: Interviews
item.description: Only by asking good questions, will you get good answers Interviews are one of the most flexible research tools available to designers, and are used in many phases of the design process to gather information from experts, users and other stakeholders.

item.title: KJ Brainstorming
item.description: Collaboratively connecting and prioritising ideas KJ Brainstorming method provides a structured approach for identifying top priorities and gaining consensus within a team.

item.title: KJ Brainstorming
item.description: Collaboratively connecting and prioritising ideas KJ Brainstorming method provides a structured approach for identifying top priorities and gaining consensus within a team.

item.title: Laddering
item.description: Finding out what really matters The laddering method is an interview technique used to discover the underlying reasons for people’s views about a product or service.

item.title: Laddering
item.description: Finding out what really matters The laddering method is an interview technique used to discover the underlying reasons for people’s views about a product or service.

item.title: Low-Fidelity Prototyping
item.description: Creating tangible representations of ideas Low-fidelity prototyping allows the quick exploration of ideas early in a design process, by creating a simple representation of an envisioned product.

item.title: Low-Fidelity Prototyping
item.description: Creating tangible representations of ideas Low-fidelity prototyping allows the quick exploration of ideas early in a design process, by creating a simple representation of an envisioned product.

item.title: Mapping Space
item.description: Capturing bodily movement through space and time Mapping space helps us to record information about the qualities of a space, how it is utilised, what the common pathways and flows are, and what volume the human body occupies within that space.

item.title: Mapping Space
item.description: Capturing bodily movement through space and time Mapping space helps us to record information about the qualities of a space, how it is utilised, what the common pathways and flows are, and what volume the human body occupies within that space.

item.title: Mindmapping (WWWWWH)
item.description: Making a snapshot of connections and relationships Mindmapping is a note-taking and notemaking technique that developed in the 1970s, emerging from cognitive research about how our brains interpret and store information.

item.title: Mindmapping (WWWWWH)
item.description: Making a snapshot of connections and relationships Mindmapping is a note-taking and notemaking technique that developed in the 1970s, emerging from cognitive research about how our brains interpret and store information.

item.title: Mockups
item.description: Creating visual models of envisioned products Mockups are scale or full-size models of products and their features. They have been used widely in the industrial design and manufacturing process to visualise the detailed representation of an envisioned product early on in a design process.

item.title: Mockups
item.description: Creating visual models of envisioned products Mockups are scale or full-size models of products and their features. They have been used widely in the industrial design and manufacturing process to visualise the detailed representation of an envisioned product early on in a design process.

item.title: Moodboards
item.description: Collecting visual inspiration Mood boards are used to visually represent design ideas, concepts and values in an open-ended and evocative way.

item.title: Moodboards
item.description: Collecting visual inspiration Mood boards are used to visually represent design ideas, concepts and values in an open-ended and evocative way.

item.title: Online Ethnography
item.description: Gathering insights from online communities Online ethnography translates the principles of traditional ethnographic studies to the study of people and their interactions online.

item.title: Online Ethnography
item.description: Gathering insights from online communities Online ethnography translates the principles of traditional ethnographic studies to the study of people and their interactions online.

item.title: Perceptual Maps
item.description: Capturing the current market landscape Perceptual maps are graphical representations of how people subjectively perceive products or consumer brands available in the market

item.title: Perceptual Maps
item.description: Capturing the current market landscape Perceptual maps are graphical representations of how people subjectively perceive products or consumer brands available in the market

item.title: Persona-based Walkthroughs
item.description: Seeing designs through the eyes of users A persona-based walkthrough takes a persona through specific tasks or scenarios, seeing the designs through their eyes.

item.title: Persona-based Walkthroughs
item.description: Seeing designs through the eyes of users A persona-based walkthrough takes a persona through specific tasks or scenarios, seeing the designs through their eyes.

item.title: Personas
item.description: Modelling users through storytelling Personas are fictional characters used to represent typical users, customers or other stakeholders, created from a synthesis of data from real people.

item.title: Personas
item.description: Modelling users through storytelling Personas are fictional characters used to represent typical users, customers or other stakeholders, created from a synthesis of data from real people.

item.title: Questionnaires
item.description: Gathering large amounts of user data Questionnaires collect information in written form and may be communicated by paper or digitally.

item.title: Questionnaires
item.description: Gathering large amounts of user data Questionnaires collect information in written form and may be communicated by paper or digitally.

item.title: Reframing
item.description: Taking a look from a different perspective Reframing techniques focus on changing the formulation of our initial problem statement, to make it broader and more abstract.

item.title: Reframing
item.description: Taking a look from a different perspective Reframing techniques focus on changing the formulation of our initial problem statement, to make it broader and more abstract.

item.title: Research Visualisation
item.description: Giving your research pride of place on the wall Research visualisations capture the most relevant results of a research process and display them in a prominent and visual manner.

item.title: Research Visualisation
item.description: Giving your research pride of place on the wall Research visualisations capture the most relevant results of a research process and display them in a prominent and visual manner.

item.title: Role-Playing
item.description: Exploring the perspectives of users The role-playing method is used to evaluate an existing design, using actors who take on one the role of a particular character and subsequently act out scenes.

item.title: Role-Playing
item.description: Exploring the perspectives of users The role-playing method is used to evaluate an existing design, using actors who take on one the role of a particular character and subsequently act out scenes.

item.title: Scenarios
item.description: Exploring designs through storytelling Scenarios ‘ also referred to as future scenarios or user stories ’ use storytelling to explore design ideas by grounding them in a real context.

item.title: Scenarios
item.description: Exploring designs through storytelling Scenarios ‘ also referred to as future scenarios or user stories ’ use storytelling to explore design ideas by grounding them in a real context.

item.title: Science Fiction Prototyping
item.description: Using the future to improve the now Science fiction prototypes are stories placed in the distant future, allowing the fictional exploration of scenarios in which people interact with envisioned products or services.

item.title: Science Fiction Prototyping
item.description: Using the future to improve the now Science fiction prototypes are stories placed in the distant future, allowing the fictional exploration of scenarios in which people interact with envisioned products or services.

item.title: Service Blueprints
item.description: Documenting the visible and the invisible Service blueprinting plots out all the different elements of a complex service in order to form a picture of the overall system.

item.title: Service Blueprints
item.description: Documenting the visible and the invisible Service blueprinting plots out all the different elements of a complex service in order to form a picture of the overall system.

item.title: Sketching
item.description: Communicating and thinking through pen and paper Sketches are tools used by designers to visually represent and depict physical aspects while composing an idea for a product or service.

item.title: Sketching
item.description: Communicating and thinking through pen and paper Sketches are tools used by designers to visually represent and depict physical aspects while composing an idea for a product or service.

item.title: Sketchnoting
item.description: Documenting processes through sketching Sketchnotes are visual notes that are a popular technique for capturing the content of a public talk or panel discussion through an illustration combining sketches and annotations

item.title: Sketchnoting
item.description: Documenting processes through sketching Sketchnotes are visual notes that are a popular technique for capturing the content of a public talk or panel discussion through an illustration combining sketches and annotations

item.title: Storyboarding
item.description: Using the power of comics to explain concepts Storyboards are hand-drawn or digitally composed drawings that are used to visually explore the interactions between people and products or services.

item.title: Storyboarding
item.description: Using the power of comics to explain concepts Storyboards are hand-drawn or digitally composed drawings that are used to visually explore the interactions between people and products or services.

item.title: Thematic Analysis
item.description: Finding patterns that make sense of what people say or write Thematic analysis is a structured method for analysing, interpreting and managing qualitative data in a way that allows us to navigate from data to ideas.

item.title: Thematic Analysis
item.description: Finding patterns that make sense of what people say or write Thematic analysis is a structured method for analysing, interpreting and managing qualitative data in a way that allows us to navigate from data to ideas.

item.title: Think-Aloud Protocol
item.description: Learning from listening to your user’s thoughts The think-aloud protocol method allows designers to gain access to people’s thought processes while they are interacting with a product or service.

item.title: Think-Aloud Protocol
item.description: Learning from listening to your user’s thoughts The think-aloud protocol method allows designers to gain access to people’s thought processes while they are interacting with a product or service.

item.title: Usability Testing
item.description: Identifying design flaws by testing early and often Usability testing allows us to determine whether people understand how to use a product, in other words, whether the conceptual model of the product matches the user’s mental model.

item.title: Usability Testing
item.description: Identifying design flaws by testing early and often Usability testing allows us to determine whether people understand how to use a product, in other words, whether the conceptual model of the product matches the user’s mental model.

item.title: User Journey Mapping
item.description: Understanding complex user experiences A user journey map is a way of presenting and describing every important step of a complex experience in a single overview.

item.title: User Journey Mapping
item.description: Understanding complex user experiences A user journey map is a way of presenting and describing every important step of a complex experience in a single overview.

item.title: User Profiles
item.description: Describing your users’ key attributes User profiles present key attributes of different identified users in an overview table that can show the full spectrum of possible users.

item.title: User Profiles
item.description: Describing your users’ key attributes User profiles present key attributes of different identified users in an overview table that can show the full spectrum of possible users.

item.title: Value Proposition Canvas
item.description: Addressing customer pains and gains The value proposition canvas method guides the process of designing a solution that addresses customers’ pain points (their issues, annoyances) and gains (what they want to achieve).

item.title: Value Proposition Canvas
item.description: Addressing customer pains and gains The value proposition canvas method guides the process of designing a solution that addresses customers’ pain points (their issues, annoyances) and gains (what they want to achieve).

item.title: Video Prototyping
item.description: Communicating design concepts through video narratives A video prototype is a short movie that explores how users would interact with a future product based on a scenario, recording these concepts in a visually rich format.

item.title: Video Prototyping
item.description: Communicating design concepts through video narratives A video prototype is a short movie that explores how users would interact with a future product based on a scenario, recording these concepts in a visually rich format.

item.title: Wireframing
item.description: Drafting a structural and functional skeleton Wireframes are line drawings that show the fundamental structure or functions of a product or system.

item.title: Wireframing
item.description: Drafting a structural and functional skeleton Wireframes are line drawings that show the fundamental structure or functions of a product or system.

item.title: Backcasting
item.description: “Working backwards to implement a preferred future” Backcasting invites us to start strategic conversations from a speculative future, by identifying the key differences between that future and today.

item.title: Backcasting
item.description: “Working backwards to implement a preferred future” Backcasting invites us to start strategic conversations from a speculative future, by identifying the key differences between that future and today.

item.title: Body Mapping
item.description: “Find out how your users feel by drawing the body inside out” A body map is composed of a simple outline of a human figure. After experiencing an interaction or situation, participants are invited to visually document their bodily experience by drawing and writing on the silhouette.

item.title: Body Mapping
item.description: “Find out how your users feel by drawing the body inside out” A body map is composed of a simple outline of a human figure. After experiencing an interaction or situation, participants are invited to visually document their bodily experience by drawing and writing on the silhouette.

item.title: Context Mapping
item.description: “Harnessing creativity to reveal hidden needs” Context mapping belongs to the family of generative research techniques in which participants make artefacts that represent their experiences and talk about these, which enables them to reflect more deeply on their lives.

item.title: Context Mapping
item.description: “Harnessing creativity to reveal hidden needs” Context mapping belongs to the family of generative research techniques in which participants make artefacts that represent their experiences and talk about these, which enables them to reflect more deeply on their lives.

item.title: Design Team Cards
item.description: “Building a strong design team by recognising and valuing attributes” The design team cards method helps team members reflect on their own attributes, using a set of predefined roles to identify how they might best contribute.

item.title: Design Team Cards
item.description: “Building a strong design team by recognising and valuing attributes” The design team cards method helps team members reflect on their own attributes, using a set of predefined roles to identify how they might best contribute.

item.title: Design Timescapes
item.description: “Making the precedents and consequences of our designs visible” Design timescapes visualise historical and future influences in an organised way, allowing us to better understand how design concepts, products and projects came into being and what the consequences of their realisation are for broader society.

item.title: Design Timescapes
item.description: “Making the precedents and consequences of our designs visible” Design timescapes visualise historical and future influences in an organised way, allowing us to better understand how design concepts, products and projects came into being and what the consequences of their realisation are for broader society.

item.title: Empathy Mapping
item.description: “Making visible the invisible to better understand your user and their experiences” Empathy mapping is a visual method that can support the understanding and interpretation of previously collected data by directly representing the experience of an individual person.

item.title: Empathy Mapping
item.description: “Making visible the invisible to better understand your user and their experiences” Empathy mapping is a visual method that can support the understanding and interpretation of previously collected data by directly representing the experience of an individual person.

item.title: Impact Ripple Canvas
item.description: “If we dont plan the world we want, we have to live with the one we get” The impact ripple canvas helps us extrapolate the consequences of a design decision outwards so we can visualise a network of secondary and tertiary actions that might spawn from the usually well thought out primary consequences.

item.title: Impact Ripple Canvas
item.description: “If we dont plan the world we want, we have to live with the one we get” The impact ripple canvas helps us extrapolate the consequences of a design decision outwards so we can visualise a network of secondary and tertiary actions that might spawn from the usually well thought out primary consequences.

item.title: Local Orbits
item.description: “Cultivating the art of observing a place” The local orbits method encourages acknowledgement of the challenges and opportunities specific to the locale within which we are designing, by cultivating our sensory perceptions of a place.

item.title: Local Orbits
item.description: “Cultivating the art of observing a place” The local orbits method encourages acknowledgement of the challenges and opportunities specific to the locale within which we are designing, by cultivating our sensory perceptions of a place.

item.title: Material Exploration
item.description: “Engaging with physical materials to find new ways of doing things” Material exploration prompts designers to select and consciously explore materials and to draw on that exploration for ways that the material could be used in a design solution.

item.title: Material Exploration
item.description: “Engaging with physical materials to find new ways of doing things” Material exploration prompts designers to select and consciously explore materials and to draw on that exploration for ways that the material could be used in a design solution.

item.title: Morphological Charts
item.description: “Breaking a big, messy problem into bite-sized pieces” Morphological charts offer a structured way of breaking a big problem down into manageable parts and tackling these one at a time, with the aim of finding the optimum solution.

item.title: Morphological Charts
item.description: “Breaking a big, messy problem into bite-sized pieces” Morphological charts offer a structured way of breaking a big problem down into manageable parts and tackling these one at a time, with the aim of finding the optimum solution.

item.title: Non-human Personas
item.description: “Giving a voice to living things and ecosystems” Non-human personas address some limitations of human-centred design methods, by adapting the personas method to give non-human stakeholders a voice in the design process.

item.title: Non-human Personas
item.description: “Giving a voice to living things and ecosystems” Non-human personas address some limitations of human-centred design methods, by adapting the personas method to give non-human stakeholders a voice in the design process.

item.title: Pop-ups
item.description: “Encouraging people to interact with temporary installations in public spaces” Pop-up installations provide an engaging way of collecting data from people in public spaces by employing a variety of formats, such as pop-up events that are located in high pedestrian thoroughfares.

item.title: Pop-ups
item.description: “Encouraging people to interact with temporary installations in public spaces” Pop-up installations provide an engaging way of collecting data from people in public spaces by employing a variety of formats, such as pop-up events that are located in high pedestrian thoroughfares.

item.title: STEP Cards
item.description: “Turning a web of external factors into actionable insights” The STEP card method can be used individually or as a group during the early stage of a project as a visual way of capturing external factors.

item.title: STEP Cards
item.description: “Turning a web of external factors into actionable insights” The STEP card method can be used individually or as a group during the early stage of a project as a visual way of capturing external factors.

item.title: Scenario-based Thinking
item.description: “Why settle for one future when you can explore four?” Scenario-based thinking allows us to generate four possible future scenarios based on local and global drivers, to understand their impact on the success or failure of the products or services we design.

item.title: Scenario-based Thinking
item.description: “Why settle for one future when you can explore four?” Scenario-based thinking allows us to generate four possible future scenarios based on local and global drivers, to understand their impact on the success or failure of the products or services we design.

item.title: Speculating Preferred Futures
item.description: “Using dystopian and utopian narratives to explore a problem area” Speculating preferred futures encourages the consideration, development and communication of new realities and new possibilities, with the aim to lead to new ideas and a deeper understanding of the problem area.

item.title: Speculating Preferred Futures
item.description: “Using dystopian and utopian narratives to explore a problem area” Speculating preferred futures encourages the consideration, development and communication of new realities and new possibilities, with the aim to lead to new ideas and a deeper understanding of the problem area.

item.title: Strategy Choice Cascade
item.description: “Improving a strategy with five key questions” The strategy choice cascade uses a collaborative way of thinking about the driving questions in strategy development, using a non-sequential pathway based on five key questions.

item.title: Strategy Choice Cascade
item.description: “Improving a strategy with five key questions” The strategy choice cascade uses a collaborative way of thinking about the driving questions in strategy development, using a non-sequential pathway based on five key questions.

item.title: Systems Mapping
item.description: “Visually identifying the components of complex systems” Systems maps support systems thinking, which is an approach to understanding how the individual components within a network influence each other. They can be represented in various ways, most of which focus on identifying causal relationships.

item.title: Systems Mapping
item.description: “Visually identifying the components of complex systems” Systems maps support systems thinking, which is an approach to understanding how the individual components within a network influence each other. They can be represented in various ways, most of which focus on identifying causal relationships.

item.title: Values Cartouche
item.description: “Visualising values to inform design decisions” Our values are fundamental to who we are and guide many of our day-to-day decisions. The values cartouche method offers an approach to identifying and articulating personal values in a visual way.

item.title: Values Cartouche
item.description: “Visualising values to inform design decisions” Our values are fundamental to who we are and guide many of our day-to-day decisions. The values cartouche method offers an approach to identifying and articulating personal values in a visual way.

item.title: Wireflows
item.description: “Visualising the relationships between wireframes” Wireflow diagrams are a quick way to visualise how individual screen designs connect to each other. The wireflow method uses elements from wireframes and flowcharts, bringing both of these communication tools together.

item.title: Wireflows
item.description: “Visualising the relationships between wireframes” Wireflow diagrams are a quick way to visualise how individual screen designs connect to each other. The wireflow method uses elements from wireframes and flowcharts, bringing both of these communication tools together.

item.title: Worst Possible Idea
item.description: “Unlocking creative thinking by encouraging terrible ideas” Giving people the permission to come up with their worst possible ideas creates a playful, safe environment and helps to get a brainstorming session off to a good start.
